  • City: BELTSVILLE
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package in question was loaded on the P&D vehicle that it was assigned it to. It was not placed in accordance to the way the orientation arrows on the packaging indicated. Combining that with the fact that one of the inner containers had a loose cap, it caused a leak of the hazardous material. The material reacted with the aluminum floor of the vehicle. The reaction caused smoke to come out as well as an extremely noxious odour. The package was taken out of the building and the FXG Emergency Spill Response line was used. DescribePack: One of the 4 inner containers had a cap that was completely loose, which lead to the leak when the package was placed on its side. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: The vehicle was taken out of the building and the package was removed thereafter.

  • Carrier/Reporter: CLI TRANSPORT, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 1
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Single vehicle fatal accident where tanker driver collided with a tree resulting in complete loss of load of 1203 around 8650 liquid gallons. Tanker ignited upon impact and ignited the rest of the load, Material entered storm sewers as burning fuel and did not contaminate any water sources. Storm sewers were flushed with 5500 gallons of water and soil was tested, resulting in no contamination. US 15 NB was closed from 12 noon until 12 midnight. Police/Fire/EMS all on scene and HAZMAT team to minimize effects.

  • City: Cumberland

  • Carrier/Reporter: KEMIRA WATER SOLUTIONS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver was heading west bound on 68 near exit 14 when he came upon dense fog with little visibility. Driver lost control and tractor trailer rolled onto its side on the side of the highway. Trailer had to be drilled and product pumped out and transferred to another trailer, so the damaged unit could be up righted with a wrecker. About 10 gallons was estimated to have leaked through the dome lid during the rollover. Emergency responders were on site immediately to mitigate the situation and assist with the product transfer and clean up as quickly as possible. Costs of loss are To Be Determined. Values entered in this report were an estimate to the best of our knowledge.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Lewis Environmental was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 5ft-by-5ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that two (2) gallon of material was released. The material was released from twenty-seven impacted boxes containing four (4) 1-gallon poly jugs. The impacted carboard, damaged bottles and personal protective equipment (PPE) were placed into two (2) 55-gallon metal drums and was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilizing. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: A FEW PACKAGES FOUND WET FROM RAIN IN SECONDARY SMALL SORT. FOLLOWING PROCEDURES, RESPONDER INSPECTED THE PACKAGES TO MAKE SURE THEY WERE NOT DAMAGED AND STARTED TO REPACK THEM. AFTER NOTIFYING SUPERVISOR, RESPONDER CALLED THE HAZMAT SUPPORT CENTER AND CONFIRMED THAT IT WAS UNDECLARED HAZMAT. RESPONDER WAS INSTRUCTED TO PROCESS IT THROUGH DMP PROCEDURES.

  • Description: THIS PACKAGE WAS PICKED UP IN THE DROP BOX BY THE COURIER WHO NOTICED A RATTLING SOUND LIKE AN AEROSOL CAN. THE SHIPPER HAD NOT OFFERED THE SHIPMENT WITH ANY DG MARKS, LABELS, NOR A SHIPPERS DECLARATION. A MANAGER OPENED THE PACKAGE AND IT DID CONTAIN TWO AEROSOL CANS OF COLOR SHOT INSTANT FABRIC COLOR (FABRIC PAINT). THIS IS UNDECLARED/HIDDEN DG, NAMELY UN 1950, AEROSOLS, FLAMMABLE, DIVISION 2.1, FLAMMABLE GAS. THE FAA WAS NOTIFIED VIA EMAIL AND PHOTOS SENT. THE PACKAGE WAS HELD PENDING FAA INVESTIGATION.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: On October 27, 2022, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3149 was damaged and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to complete the necessary corrective actions. MEG personnel utilized neutralizing agents, absorbents, and hand tools to remediate the impacted surface. The damaged drum was placed in one (1) 95-gallon overpack and all UN3149-impacted material was containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 2, 2022, one (1) 300-gallon tote of paint was damaged and released approximately one hundred (100) gallons of product to the trailer floor and asphalt surface beneath. R + L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to complete the necessary corrective actions. FCE personnel utilized an absorbent boom and patching to contain the release to the trailer. FCE then followed the driver to the terminal, ensuring no release to the roadway. RLC manager took over the incident and stated the remediation would be completed at a later time.

item.title: Report E-2022100391
item.description:
Report E-2022100391

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-26T21:10:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-18
  • City: BRUNSWICK
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 18, 2022, at approximately 15:07 hours, personnel in the CSX Brunswick, MD yard discovered SVCX 80505, a residue tank car of Hydrogen Chloride was leaking vapors from the top of the car. The release was due to product leaking between the pressure relief device and the tank cars pressure plate. The car was isolated and the shipper, SI Group, was notified via CHEMTREC report 2022-0918-00025. Specialized Professional Services, Inc., (SPSI), a CSX emergency response contractor, was dispatched to assist with the release. Response personnel from SPSI and CSXs Hazardous Materials Team installed a Midland Emergency Capping Kit to contain the product release. Response personnel then worked to safely purge the car of all residual vapor so the car could be move to home shop for repair as a clean/empty car.
